awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: New Insights into STEM Pathways: The Role of Peers, Networks, and Demand.
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is a collaborative effort involving researchers from New York University, Ohio State University, and University of Michigan Ann Arbor who are extending work on a previous project that links multiple data sets to conduct longitudinal analyses of STEM student outcomes. The current project leverages the research infrastructure that was supported by prior awards to examine how peer effects, network connections, and employer demand shape career outcomes for doctoral students. It integrates comprehensive administrative data for 113,000 doctoral students, UMETRICS research data, Proquest data on dissertations with information on fields of study and research, and restricted Census Bureau data on earnings and employment outcomes. Dara integration will occur under the umbrella of the Institute for Research on Innovation and Science (IRIS). The project will contribute new knowledge by articulating and testing key aspects of a novel conceptual model of STEM career choices. This theoretical and empirical work will establish basic facts about how demand and training conditions shape early STEM career choices that can be determine only through the integration of separate datasets. The project is supported by the Education and Human Resources Core Research Program, which funds fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

The research design integrates three approaches - peer-based, network-based, and demand. In their peer-based approach, the researchers propose to take the composition of peers in entering graduate cohorts to be quasi-random and estimate how the composition of peers interacts with their own characteristics. A second set of analyses involves identifying labs from the data and estimating how the composition of the persons in a lab relate to outcomes. The network-based approach will be used to examine how individual differences in social capital shape doctoral student outcomes. The demand will answer the analytical question of the effect of actual and perceived labor market demand on the choice of careers. The analysis will begin with a description of the early career outcomes of students from undergraduate dropouts to college graduates, from master's students to Ph.D. dropouts to doctoral recipients.  In addition to enhancing the infrastructure to conduct robust workforce development research, the project will provide a more comprehensive analysis of the role and impact of peer networks on STEM workforce development

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Graduate education in Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (STEM) fields does several important things for individual students, for employers and for society.   Doctoral recipients in these fields contribute to academic research and to innovation in both new startups and established businesses. The highly skilled technical workforce they make up is a key component of both national prosperity and international competitiveness.  But recent research and reports by the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine demonstrate that STEM graduate education is not equally accessible to students from all backgrounds and may not effectively prepare all students for the range of academic and non-academic careers they might pursue.  As a result, concerns have been expressed about whether STEM graduate education is as effective as it could be in contributing to the health, wealth, and well-being of society.

 

This project developed and used big data on the research careers of graduate students and the faculty-led projects and teams that they worked on along with information about their academic programs and other types of data to look at the pathways students in different fields and from different backgrounds follow through graduate school and into the workforce.  By looking at differences in such pathways, we studied how the early careers of STEM trainees are shaped by the networks in which they are embedded, peers, and mentors, with a particular emphasis on women and members of underrepresented groups. This work provides a broader understanding of the challenges doctoral students face and the ways that graduate education might be altered to improve outcomes for students, employers, and society as a whole

 

In addition to supporting research that led to 12 published or working papers and 3 books, our project led to the construction of a dataset that has been used by more than 350 researchers from nearly 115 universities around the country to do additional research to understand, explain, and hopefully improve the public value of academic research. Our research and that data has also had numerous broader impacts. It was a component of two new initiatives at the U.S. Census Bureau, a pilot project with the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, and work in the Executive Branch in response to the Evidence-Based Policy Act of 2018.   Various forms of the data have also been used as part of the training of 11 graduate students and post-docs on our projects and in workshops on large scale data analysis that have included 60 federal , state, and local agency staff and nearly 250 students, trainees, and faculty from around the country including 40 faculty from Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Hispanic Serving Institutions.  Finally, our work has been used by universities, federal agencies and congress to help understand the effects of the pandemic on graduate education and on academic science. That understanding has informed policies developed in response to pandemic interruptions in research including bills introduced into the congress.

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2022
Modified by: Jason Owen-Smith
